title: Are deprecated
content: Container queries require container setup. Explain container-type and container-name for container queries.
explanation: container-type: inline-size (queries width), size (queries width and height), normal (not a container). container-name: names container for <cod@container queries. Must set container-type to enable container queries. Use @container (name) size queries.

options.text: container-type: enables container queries (inline-size/size); container-name: names container for queries
options.explanation: Correct. These properties enable container queries.
Incorrect. They serve different purposes.
Incorrect. They enable container queries, not media queries.
Incorrect. They're modern features for container queries.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Fixed pixel values (not responsive)
content: Grid provides responsive capabilities. Identify Grid features that enable responsive layouts without media queries.
explanation: auto-fit/auto-fill with minmax() create responsive columns. fr units distribute space flexibly. min-content, max-content adapt to content. repeat(auto-fit, minmax(<cod200px, <cod1fr)) creates responsive grid. No media queries needed.

options.explanation: Correct. auto-fit/auto-fill enable responsive grids.
Correct. fr units are flexible.
Correct. These adapt to content.
Incorrect. Fixed pixels are not responsive.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: margins are always better
content: Gap property simplifies spacing. Explain gap vs margins and when to use each.
explanation: gap: spacing between flex/grid items (row-gap, column-gap). Only works in Flexbox/Grid. Margins: spacing around any element, works everywhere. gap is simpler (no negative margins, no first/last child exceptions), margins more flexible but more complex.

options.text: gap: spacing between items in Flexbox/Grid; simpler than margins, no edge cases
options.explanation: Correct. gap is cleaner for Flexbox/Grid spacing.
Incorrect. gap only works in Flexbox/Grid.
Incorrect. gap only works in Flexbox/Grid contexts.
Incorrect. gap is often simpler for Flexbox/Grid.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: justify-content (main axis, not cross axis)
content: Flexbox cross-axis alignment requires specific properties. Identify properties that control cross-axis alignment.
explanation: Cross-axis alignment: align-items (all items), align-self (individual item), align-content (wrapped lines). These work on cross axis (perpendicular to main axis). justify-content works on main axis.

options.explanation: Correct. align-items controls cross-axis alignment.
Correct. align-self overrides align-items.
Correct. align-content aligns wrapped content.
Incorrect. justify-content works on main axis.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: Masonry is a proposed Grid feature. Explain masonry layout and its implementation status.
explanation: Masonry: Pinterest-style layout where items flow into shortest column. Proposed for CSS Grid but not yet standardized. Firefox has experimental support behind flag. Workaround: use JavaScript libraries or column-based approaches. Not production-ready yet.

options.text: Pinterest-style layout; experimental, not standardized; limited browser support
options.explanation: Correct. Masonry is experimental.
Incorrect. Masonry is not yet standardized.
Incorrect. Support is very limited.
Incorrect. It's a proposed feature, not deprecated.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: Grid automatically places items. Explain the auto-placement algorithm and how items flow into the grid.
explanation: Auto-placement: items flow row by row, left to right. grid-auto-flow controls direction: row (default, left-right), column (top-bottom), dense (fills gaps). Items without explicit placement use auto-placement. Can specify grid-auto-flow: dense to fill gaps.

options.text: Items flow row by row (default); grid-auto-flow controls direction and gap-filling
options.explanation: Correct. Auto-placement follows grid-auto-flow rules.
Incorrect. Placement follows specific algorithm.
Incorrect. Auto-placement works when no explicit placement.
Incorrect. Auto-placement is a core Grid feature.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: align-items only works with single line
content: Flexbox has two alignment properties for cross axis. Explain the difference between align-items and align-content.
explanation: align-items: aligns items within each line (single-line or multi-line). align-content: aligns lines when content wraps (only works with flex-wrap: wrap). align-items: per-line alignment. align-content: between-lines spacing. Use align-items for item alignment, align-content for line spacing.

options.text: align-items: items within lines; align-content: spacing between wrapped lines
options.explanation: Correct. They control different aspects of alignment.
Incorrect. They work on different levels.
Incorrect. Both are valid and useful.

options.text: align-items only works with single line
options.explanation: Incorrect. align-items works with wrapped content too.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: justify-content (alignment, not sizing)
content: Flexbox sizing controls how items grow and shrink. Identify properties that control item sizing.
explanation: flex-grow: growth factor (how much item grows). flex-shrink: shrink factor (how much item shrinks). flex-basis: initial size. flex: shorthand (grow shrink basis). min-width/max-width also affect sizing. These control how items use available space.

options.explanation: Correct. flex-grow controls growth.
Correct. flex-shrink controls shrinking.
Correct. flex-basis sets initial size.
Incorrect. justify-content controls alignment, not sizing.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Only works with JavaScript
content: Sticky positioning has specific requirements. Explain what''s needed for sticky to function correctly.
explanation: Requirements: top/left/right/bottom must be set (defines stick point). Parent container must have space (can't overflow). Works within containing block. If parent has overflow: hidden/scroll, sticky may not work. Needs scrollable ancestor.

options.text: Requires top/left/right/bottom value; parent must allow scrolling; can break with overflow: hidden
options.explanation: Correct. Sticky has specific requirements.
Incorrect. Requires positioning values.
Incorrect. Parent properties affect it.
Incorrect. Sticky is pure CSS.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Only grid-template-rows works
content: Grid row definition has multiple approaches. Explain grid-template-rows vs grid-auto-rows and when to use each.
explanation: grid-template-rows: defines explicit rows (named or sized). grid-auto-rows: defines size for implicit rows (created automatically when items exceed explicit rows). Use template for known structure, auto for dynamic content. Can combine both.

options.text: grid-template-rows: explicit rows; grid-auto-rows: implicit/auto-created rows
options.explanation: Correct. Template is for explicit, auto is for implicit rows.
Incorrect. They define different row types.
Incorrect. Both are valid and useful.
Incorrect. Both serve different purposes.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: Subgrid is an advanced Grid feature. Explain its purpose, use cases, and browser support.
explanation: subgrid allows nested grid to inherit parent's grid tracks. Solves alignment in nested grids. Without subgrid, nested grids are independent. With subgrid, child aligns with parent. Limited support: Firefox 71+, Safari 16+. Use for card layouts, complex nested structures.

options.text: Inherits parent grid tracks for alignment; limited browser support (Firefox, Safari)
options.explanation: Correct. subgrid solves nested grid alignment.
Incorrect. That's regular nested grid, not subgrid.
Incorrect. Browser support is limited.
Incorrect. subgrid is a modern feature.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Only work on inline elements
content: Text pseudo-elements style specific parts. Explain first-line vs first-letter and their use cases.
explanation: <cod::first-line styles first line of block element (wraps based on width). <cod::first-letter styles first letter (drop caps, styling). <cod::first-line can style multiple words, <cod::first-letter is single character. Both only work on block-level elements.

options.text: <cod::first-line: entire first line; <cod::first-letter: single first character
options.explanation: Correct. They target different scopes.
Incorrect. They target different parts of text.
Incorrect. ::first-letter only styles the first character.
Incorrect. They work on block-level elements.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Specificity doesn't matter
content: Understanding cascade order is crucial. Explain how source order affects which styles are applied.
explanation: When specificity is equal, later rules win (source order). Stylesheet order matters: earlier < later. Inline styles (highest specificity) embedded < external. Within same specificity, last declared wins. This is why order matters in CSS.

options.text: Later rules win when specificity is equal (source order determines winner)
options.explanation: Correct. Source order breaks ties when specificity is equal.
Incorrect. Later rules win when specificity is equal.
Incorrect. Source order determines the winner.
Incorrect. Specificity matters first, then source order.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: color (inherited)
content: Understanding inheritance helps write efficient CSS. Identify properties that are not inherited.
explanation: Non-inherited: margin, padding, border, width, height, display, position, float, clear, background, z-index, overflow, text-decoration (some values), vertical-align. These must be set on each element or use 'inherit' keyword.

options.explanation: Correct. margin is not inherited.
Correct. padding is not inherited.
Correct. width and height are not inherited.
Incorrect. color is inherited.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Attribute selectors don't work
content: Attribute selectors provide powerful targeting. Explain different attribute selector syntaxes and their meanings.
explanation: <cod[attr]: element has attribute. <cod[attr=value]: exact match. [attr~=value]: value in space-separated list. [attr|=value]: value or value- prefix. [attr^=value]: starts with. [attr$=value]: ends with. [attr*=value]: contains substring.

options.text: <cod[attr]: has attribute; <cod[attr=value]: exact match; [attr~=value]: in space-separated list
options.explanation: Correct. Different operators match differently.
Incorrect. They match differently.
Incorrect. ~= means in space-separated list.
Incorrect. Attribute selectors are powerful and widely supported.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Require JavaScript to work
content: CSS variables have scoping rules. Explain how custom properties inherit and can be overridden.
explanation: CSS variables inherit (cascade down). Define at <cod:root for global scope. Override in any selector for local scope. Child elements inherit parent's variable values. Use var(--name, fallback) for fallback values. Scoped to selector and descendants.

options.text: Variables inherit down the DOM tree; can be overridden in any selector for local scope
options.explanation: Correct. CSS variables cascade and can be scoped.
Incorrect. CSS variables do inherit.
Incorrect. Variables can be defined at any level.
Incorrect. CSS variables are pure CSS.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: em (relative to parent)
content: Viewport units enable responsive sizing. Identify CSS units that are relative to viewport dimensions.
explanation: Viewport units: vw (viewport width 1%), vh (viewport height 1%), vmin (smaller of vw/vh), vmax (larger of vw/vh). These are relative to viewport size, not parent elements. Useful for full-screen layouts, hero sections.

options.explanation: Correct. vw is relative to viewport width.
Correct. vh is relative to viewport height.
Correct. vmin is relative to smaller viewport dimension.
Incorrect. em is relative to parent, not viewport.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: <cod:has() is a powerful modern selector. Explain its purpose, use cases, and browser support considerations.
explanation: e:has() is parent selector - selects parent based on child. Example: div<cod:has(> img) selects divs containing img. Solves 'parent selector problem'. Limited browser support (Safari 15<cod.4+, Chrome 105+). Enables conditional styling based on content.

options.text: Parent selector - selects element based on descendants; limited browser support
options.explanation: Correct. :has() enables parent selection.
Incorrect. :has() selects the parent based on children.
Incorrect. Browser support is limited.
Incorrect. :has() is a modern, powerful feature.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: <cod:nth-of-type is deprecated
content: Advanced selectors enable precise targeting. Explain nth-child vs nth-of-type and when to use each.

options.explanation: Correct. They select based on different criteria.
Incorrect. They work differently.
Incorrect. nth-child works with any element.
Incorrect. Both are standard CSS selectors.

resources.title: CSS nth-child() vs nth-of-type() Explained
resources.author: Web Dev Simplified
resources.description: Learn the difference between nth-child and nth-of-type selectors

resources.title: Understanding CSS :nth-child() and :nth-of-type()
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Complete guide to CSS nth-child and nth-of-type selectors

title: Both are deprecated
content: Modern CSS provides selector grouping functions. Explain <cod:is() and <cod:where() and their specificity differences.
explanation: <cod:is(selector1, selector2) groups selectors, specificity = most specific in group. <cod:where(selector1, selector2) groups selectors, specificity = 0 (always). <cod:is() maintains specificity, <cod:where() resets it. Use <cod:where() to avoid specificity conflicts, <cod:is() when you need specificity.

options.explanation: Correct. This is the key difference.
Incorrect. They handle specificity differently.
Incorrect. :where() has zero specificity.
Incorrect. Both are modern, useful features.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: <cod::hover (not a pseudo-element, it's a pseudo-class)
content: Pseudo-elements create virtual elements. Identify valid pseudo-elements in CSS.
explanation: Valid pseudo-elements: <cod::before, <cod::after, <cod::first-line, <cod::first-letter, <cod::selection, <cod::placeholder, <cod::backdrop. Double colon (::) is modern syntax, single colon (:) works for backward compatibility. <cod::before and <cod::after require content property.

options.explanation: Correct. ::before is a valid pseudo-element.
Correct. ::after is a valid pseudo-element.
Correct. ::first-letter is a valid pseudo-element.
Incorrect. ::hover is a pseudo-class, not pseudo-element.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Only !important solves conflicts
content: Specificity wars are a problem. Explain how CSS methodologies prevent specificity conflicts.
explanation: Large codebases: specificity conflicts, !important overuse, hard to override. Methodologies help: BEM (flat specificity), ITCSS (layered specificity), OOCSS (avoid nesting). Consistent naming, flat selectors, avoid deep nesting. Prevents specificity wars.

options.text: Methodologies provide flat specificity (BEM), layered structure (ITCSS) to prevent conflicts
options.explanation: Correct. Methodologies prevent specificity issues.
Incorrect. They help prevent conflicts.
Incorrect. Methodologies help prevent them.
Incorrect. !important is an anti-pattern.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Requires JavaScript
content: ITCSS provides a layered CSS architecture. Explain its inverted triangle structure and layer organization.
explanation: ITCSS: Inverted Triangle CSS. Layers (bottom to top): Settings (variables), Tools (mixins), Generic (resets), Elements (base styles), Objects (layout), Components (UI), Utilities (helpers). Specificity increases upward. Prevents specificity conflicts.

options.text: Organizes CSS in layers from generic to specific; prevents specificity conflicts
options.explanation: Correct. ITCSS provides layered architecture.
Incorrect. ITCSS is a methodology, not a tool.
Incorrect. ITCSS is a valid methodology.
Incorrect. ITCSS is a CSS organization method.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Requires JavaScript
content: CSS architecture requires methodologies. Explain BEM naming convention and its structure.
explanation: BEM: Block__Element<cod--Modifier. Block: standalone component (button). Element: part of block (button__icon). Modifier: variation (button<cod--primary). Naming: <cod.block__element--modifier. Benefits: clear structure, avoids specificity issues, self-documenting.

options.text: Block__Element<cod--Modifier: component, part, variation; clear naming structure
options.explanation: Correct. BEM provides clear, maintainable naming.
Incorrect. BEM works with any CSS.
Incorrect. BEM is widely used.
Incorrect. BEM is a CSS naming convention.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: One large CSS file (anti-pattern)
content: Large projects need organization. Identify strategies for managing complex CSS codebases.
explanation: Modular files (partials), naming conventions (BEM), component-based organization, utility classes, CSS-in-JS (for component frameworks), design tokens, style guides, documentation. All help maintain large codebases.

options.explanation: Correct. Modularity improves organization.
Correct. Consistent naming helps maintainability.
Correct. Component organization scales well.
Incorrect. Large files are hard to maintain.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: One massive file (anti-pattern)
content: File structure affects maintainability. Identify effective CSS file organization strategies.
explanation: Component-based (one file per component), feature-based (grouped by feature), layer-based (ITCSS), utility files (separate utilities), vendor files (third-party), main file (imports all). Choose based on project size and team preference.

options.explanation: Correct. Component organization scales well.
Correct. Feature organization works for large apps.
Correct. Layer organization prevents conflicts.
Incorrect. Large files are hard to maintain.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Requires SASS
content: Object-Oriented CSS provides principles. Explain OOCSS and its core concepts.
explanation: OOCSS: Object-Oriented CSS. Principles: 1) Separate structure (layout) from skin (visual), 2) Separate container from content. Reusable objects, avoid location-dependent styles. Enables code reuse, maintainability. Example: <cod.button (structure) + <cod.button-primary (skin).

options.text: Separates structure (layout) from skin (visual); enables reusable objects
options.explanation: Correct. OOCSS promotes reusability.
Incorrect. OOCSS is a principle, works with any selectors.
Incorrect. OOCSS principles are still valid.
Incorrect. OOCSS works with plain CSS.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Require JavaScript
content: Design systems use tokens. Explain CSS design tokens and their role in maintaining design consistency.
explanation: Design tokens: named values (colors, spacing, typography) stored as CSS variables. Single source of truth, ensures consistency, easy theming, maintainable. Example: <cod--color-primary: #007bff. Used throughout codebase, changed in one place.

options.text: Named values (colors, spacing) as CSS variables; single source of truth for consistency
options.explanation: Correct. Design tokens ensure consistency.
Incorrect. Design tokens work with CSS variables.
Incorrect. Design tokens are modern best practice.
Incorrect. Design tokens are CSS variables.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Inline styles (not a methodology)
content: CSS organization requires methodologies. Identify popular CSS architecture approaches.
explanation: BEM (Block Element Modifier), OOCSS (Object-Oriented), SMACSS (Scalable and Modular), ITCSS (Inverted Triangle), Atomic CSS, Utility-first (Tailwind approach). Each has different organization principles.

options.explanation: Correct. BEM is a popular methodology.
Correct. OOCSS is a methodology.
Correct. SMACSS is a methodology.
Incorrect. This is not a CSS architecture methodology.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Component-based only works with React
content: CSS approaches differ. Explain utility-first vs component-based CSS and their trade-offs.
explanation: Utility-first: small utility classes (flex, p-4, text-center), compose in HTML, less custom CSS, faster development, larger HTML. Component-based: semantic classes, styles in CSS, more maintainable CSS, cleaner HTML. Tailwind is utility-first, BEM is component-based.

options.text: Utility-first: compose in HTML; Component-based: semantic classes in CSS
options.explanation: Correct. Different approaches with different trade-offs.
Incorrect. They have fundamentally different approaches.
Incorrect. Utility-first is popular (Tailwind).
Incorrect. Component-based CSS works with any framework.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Cannot be changed dynamically
content: Theming requires flexible CSS. Explain how CSS custom properties enable dynamic theming systems.
explanation: CSS custom properties (<cod--variable) enable runtime theming. Define theme variables at <cod:root, override in themes. Change with JavaScript (setProperty). Enables dark mode, user preferences, dynamic themes. More flexible than SASS variables (compile-time).

options.text: Runtime variables enable dynamic theming; change with JS; supports dark mode, user preferences
options.explanation: Correct. CSS variables enable dynamic theming.
Incorrect. CSS variables work at runtime.
Incorrect. CSS custom properties are native CSS.
Incorrect. CSS variables can be changed with JavaScript.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Only needed for mobile
content: Performance optimization requires understanding Critical CSS. Explain its purpose and implementation.
explanation: Critical CSS: above-the-fold styles needed for initial render. Inline in <head to avoid render-blocking. Remaining CSS loads asynchronously. Improves First Contentful Paint (FCP), reduces render-blocking. Essential for performance.

options.text: Above-the-fold styles inlined in head; improves First Contentful Paint
options.explanation: Correct. Critical CSS reduces render-blocking.
Incorrect. Critical CSS is only above-the-fold styles.
Incorrect. Critical CSS loads first, inline.
Incorrect. Critical CSS helps on all devices.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Increases rendering cost
content: CSS containment is a performance feature. Explain the contain property and its optimization benefits.
explanation: contain: isolates element's rendering (layout, style, paint, size). Prevents changes from affecting outside. Optimizes: layout (contain: layout), paint (contain: paint), style recalculation. Use on isolated components. Improves performance for complex pages.

options.text: Isolates element rendering; prevents changes from affecting outside; optimizes layout/paint
options.explanation: Correct. Containment optimizes rendering scope.
Incorrect. contain optimizes, doesn't hide.
Incorrect. contain works with any layout.
Incorrect. contain reduces rendering cost.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Load all CSS synchronously
content: CSS delivery affects page load. Identify strategies that improve CSS loading and rendering performance.
explanation: Critical CSS inline, non-critical async, HTTP/2 server push, preload for critical CSS, code splitting, CDN delivery, compression (gzip/brotli), remove unused CSS, minification.

options.explanation: Correct. Inline critical CSS reduces render-blocking.
Correct. Preload prioritizes critical resources.
Correct. Code splitting reduces initial payload.
Incorrect. Async loading is better for non-critical CSS.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Adding more comments
content: Smaller CSS files load faster. Identify techniques that reduce CSS file size.
explanation: Minification (remove whitespace, comments), unused CSS removal (PurgeCSS), compression (gzip/brotli), code splitting, removing duplicate rules, using shorthand properties, avoiding !important overuse.

options.explanation: Correct. Minification reduces file size.
Correct. Removing unused CSS reduces size.
Correct. Compression reduces transfer size.
Incorrect. Comments increase file size.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: opacity (GPU-accelerated, no layout)
content: Layout performance matters. Identify properties that trigger layout (reflow) and should be avoided in animations.
explanation: Layout-triggering properties: width, height, margin, padding, border, display, position (static/relative), top/left/right/bottom, font-size, line-height. These cause reflow (expensive). Use transform/opacity for animations instead.

options.explanation: Correct. These trigger expensive layout.
Correct. These trigger layout recalculation.
Incorrect. transform doesn't trigger layout.
Incorrect. opacity doesn't trigger layout.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Only works with system fonts
content: Web fonts can block rendering. Explain font-display and its impact on performance and user experience.
explanation: font-display controls font rendering: block (invisible until loaded, FOIT), swap (show fallback immediately, FOUT), fallback (short block then swap), optional (only if cached). swap is best for performance, prevents invisible text.

options.text: Controls font rendering strategy; swap shows fallback immediately (best for performance)
options.explanation: Correct. swap prevents invisible text.
Incorrect. font-display controls rendering, not file size.
Incorrect. font-display is a modern, important feature.
Incorrect. font-display works with web fonts.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Increases layout calculations
content: Layout containment is a performance feature. Explain contain: layout and its optimization benefits.
explanation: contain: layout isolates element's layout calculations. Changes inside don't affect outside layout. Browser can skip layout calculations for outside elements. Use on isolated components. Improves performance for complex layouts.

options.text: Isolates layout calculations; changes inside don't affect outside; optimizes performance
options.explanation: Correct. Layout containment optimizes calculations.
Incorrect. It optimizes layout, doesn't prevent it.
Incorrect. contain works with any layout method.
Incorrect. It reduces layout calculations.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Increases rendering time
content: Modern CSS provides rendering optimizations. Explain content-visibility and its performance benefits.
explanation: content-visibility: auto skips rendering off-screen content until needed. Significantly improves initial render for long pages. Similar to lazy loading but for rendering. Use on sections that are initially off-screen. Limited browser support.

options.text: Skips rendering off-screen content until needed; improves initial render performance
options.explanation: Correct. content-visibility optimizes rendering.
Incorrect. It defers rendering, doesn't hide.
Incorrect. content-visibility is pure CSS.
Incorrect. It reduces rendering time.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Non-blocking CSS doesn't work
content: CSS loading affects page performance. Explain render-blocking vs non-blocking CSS and optimization strategies.
explanation: Render-blocking: CSS in <head blocks HTML parsing until loaded (default). Non-blocking: load asynchronously (media='print' then switch, or load via JS). Critical CSS inline, non-critical async. Improves Time to First Byte, FCP.

options.text: Render-blocking: blocks parsing (default); Non-blocking: async loading for non-critical CSS
options.explanation: Correct. Non-blocking improves performance.
Incorrect. They affect performance differently.
Incorrect. Non-critical CSS should load async.
Incorrect. Non-blocking CSS is a valid optimization.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: will-change isolates rendering
content: Both properties optimize performance. Explain when to use will-change vs contain and their different purposes.
explanation: will-change: hints about upcoming changes, promotes to GPU layer, use for animations about to start. contain: isolates rendering scope, prevents cascade effects, use for isolated components. Different purposes: will-change for animations, contain for isolation.

options.text: will-change: animation optimization; contain: rendering isolation for components
options.explanation: Correct. They optimize different aspects.
Incorrect. They serve different optimization purposes.
Incorrect. Both are modern features.
Incorrect. That's contain's purpose.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: CSS variables require a preprocessor
content: CSS now has native variables. Explain CSS custom properties vs SASS variables and when to use each.
explanation: CSS custom properties: native CSS, runtime values (can change with JS), cascade, scoped. SASS variables: compile-time, static, no runtime access. Use CSS variables for theming, dynamic values. Use SASS for compile-time constants, calculations.

options.text: CSS variables: runtime, dynamic, cascade; SASS: compile-time, static
options.explanation: Correct. CSS variables are more powerful for dynamic theming.
Incorrect. CSS variables are runtime, SASS is compile-time.
Incorrect. CSS variables enable dynamic theming.
Incorrect. CSS variables are native CSS.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Native browser support (no compilation needed)
content: CSS preprocessors add features. Identify the main advantages SASS provides over vanilla CSS.
explanation: SASS advantages: variables, nesting, mixins, functions, partials/modularity, inheritance (<cod@extend), operators. Enables DRY code, better organization, maintainability. Compiles to CSS.

options.explanation: Correct. Variables enable DRY code.
Correct. Nesting improves organization.
Correct. Mixins enable code reuse.
Incorrect. SASS requires compilation to CSS.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: <cod@mixin is deprecated
content: SASS provides two code reuse mechanisms. Explain extend vs mixin and their trade-offs.
explanation: <cod@extend: shares selector (groups selectors), less CSS output, but can create specificity issues, less flexible. <cod@mixin: duplicates code (more output), more flexible with parameters, clearer intent. Prefer <cod@mixin for flexibility, <cod@extend for simple sharing.

options.text: <cod@extend: shares selector; <cod@mixin: duplicates code with parameters (more flexible)
options.explanation: Correct. Mixins are generally more flexible.
Incorrect. They work differently.
Incorrect. Mixins are often preferred for flexibility.
Incorrect. Both are valid and useful.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Inline styles (not a SASS feature)
content: SASS provides organizational features. Identify features that improve CSS code structure.
explanation: Partials (<cod@import/_file<cod.scss): modular files. <cod@use/<cod@forward: modern module system. Nesting: hierarchical structure. Mixins: reusable blocks. Functions: reusable logic. All help organize and maintain CSS.

options.explanation: Correct. Partials enable modular organization.
Correct. Nesting improves organization.
Correct. Mixins enable code reuse.
Incorrect. This is not a SASS organizational feature.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: PostCSS only works with React
content: PostCSS is a different type of CSS tool. Explain its purpose and how it compares to preprocessors.
explanation: PostCSS: CSS transformer (not preprocessor), plugin-based, processes CSS with JavaScript. SASS/LESS: preprocessors, compile to CSS. PostCSS can add features (autoprefixer, nesting), optimize, lint. More flexible, modern approach. Often used with preprocessors.

options.text: PostCSS: CSS transformer with plugins; SASS/LESS: preprocessors that compile to CSS
options.explanation: Correct. PostCSS is more flexible and plugin-based.
Incorrect. PostCSS is a transformer, not a preprocessor.
Incorrect. They can work together.
Incorrect. PostCSS is framework-agnostic.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: SCSS only works with JavaScript
content: SASS has two syntaxes. Explain the differences and use cases for each.
explanation: SCSS: CSS-like syntax, uses braces and semicolons, easier migration from CSS. SASS: indented syntax, no braces/semicolons, more concise. SCSS is more popular, easier for teams. SASS is more concise but less familiar.

options.text: SCSS: CSS-like with braces; SASS: indented syntax, more concise
options.explanation: Correct. SCSS is more popular and familiar.
Incorrect. They have different syntaxes.
Incorrect. Both syntaxes are valid.
Incorrect. SCSS is a CSS preprocessor.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Is deprecated
content: Browser prefixes are tedious. Explain autoprefixer and how it automates vendor prefixing.
explanation: autoprefixer: PostCSS plugin that automatically adds vendor prefixes (-webkit-, -moz-, -ms-) based on browser support data. Write modern CSS, autoprefixer adds needed prefixes. Keeps CSS clean, ensures compatibility, uses Can I Use data.

options.text: Automatically adds vendor prefixes based on browser support data
options.explanation: Correct. autoprefixer automates prefixing.
Incorrect. It adds prefixes, not removes them.
Incorrect. autoprefixer works with any CSS.
Incorrect. autoprefixer is widely used.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Native browser support without compilation
content: LESS is another CSS preprocessor. Identify features it shares with SASS.
explanation: Both LESS and SASS provide: variables, nesting, mixins, functions, imports. SASS has more features (extend, advanced functions). LESS can run in browser (JavaScript), SASS requires compilation. Both compile to CSS.

options.explanation: Correct. Both support variables.
Correct. Both support nesting.
Correct. Both support mixins.
Incorrect. Both require compilation (though LESS can run client-side).

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS

title: Only works with LESS
content: CSS optimization tools reduce file size. Explain cssnano and its optimization techniques.
explanation: cssnano: PostCSS plugin that minifies CSS. Removes whitespace, comments, unused rules, optimizes values, merges rules. Reduces file size significantly. Essential for production builds. Part of modern build pipelines.

options.text: Minifies CSS: removes whitespace, comments, optimizes values for smaller file size
options.explanation: Correct. cssnano optimizes CSS for production.
Incorrect. That's autoprefixer.
Incorrect. cssnano minifies already-compiled CSS.
Incorrect. cssnano works with any CSS.

resources.title: CSS-Tricks
resources.author: CSS-Tricks
resources.description: Tips, tricks, and techniques for CSS
